paper_metadata.title: The Samata intervention to increase secondary school completion and reduce child marriage among adolescent girls: results from a cluster-randomised control trial in India

program_information.region: Vijayapura and Bagalkote districts, Karnataka State

study_characteristics.outcomes_evidence_citation: Primary trial outcomes were proportion of girls who completed secondary school and were married, by trial end-line (15-16 years)
study_characteristics.design_evidence_citation: 80 of 121 villages in Vijayapura and Bagalkote districts, Karnataka State, were randomly selected (control = 40; intervention = 40)

evidence_citations.program_name_citation: The Samata intervention to increase secondary school completion and reduce child marriage among adolescent girls
evidence_citations.country_citation: 80 of 121 villages in Vijayapura and Bagalkote districts, Karnataka State, were randomly selected
evidence_citations.target_population_citation: We tested whether a structural and norms-based intervention, which worked with adolescent girls, their families, communities, and secondary schools to address poverty, schooling quality and gender norms, could reduce secondary school drop-out and child marriage among scheduled-caste/scheduled-tribe (SC/ ST) adolescent girls in rural settings of southern India
